title: Cardiac Tamponade from Penetrating Trauma
diagnosis_topic: Pericardial tamponade secondary to stab wound to the chest
setup_script: A 32-year-old man is rushed to the ED after being stabbed in the left precordium. He is lethargic and complains of chest pressure. There is a 3 cm stab wound over the fifth intercostal space.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 85/60 mmHg, HR 130 bpm, RR 30/min, SpO2 92% on oxygen.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident observes jugular venous distension and muffled heart sounds

dynamic_flow.reply: Pericardial view shows large anechoic fluid collection surrounding the heart with collapse of right atrium.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prepares for emergent pericardiocentesis in ED
dynamic_flow.reply: Needle decompression yields dark blood; hemodynamics transiently improve.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for operating room thoracotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Median sternotomy performed to repair right ventricular laceration and evacuate clot.
Patient deteriorates rapidly into pulseless electrical activity.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about indications for ED thoracotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Penetrating chest trauma with witnessed signs of life and loss of pulses is an indication.
Monitor for arrhythmias, bleeding, and recurrent tamponade; consider ICU.
Crossmatched blood should be used rather than returning pericardial blood due to contamination.
Tamponade impairs cardiac filling leading to obstructive shock.
FAST can rapidly identify pericardial effusion in trauma.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of cardiac tamponade and obstructive shock
Use of FAST to diagnose pericardial effusion
Emergent pericardiocentesis and definitive surgical repair
Avoiding delays that lead to cardiac arrest
